title.narrative: Youth Education and Leadership through HELP

description.narrative:
Haiti’s staggering rates of “brain drain” (84%: the highest in the world) and university enrollment (1% among the lowest in the world) are among the primary obstacles to meaningful socioeconomic development across the country. The lack of local skilled labor, effective management, educated leadership, and institutional capacity are recognized as significant impediments to progress at all levels. By supporting professional training and internships, as well as leadership development and community service experience to students in HELP’s comprehensive univeristy scholarship program, this project contributes to increasing economic opportunities for young Haitians while also building technical capacity in country. The goal of this project is for HELP’s student body of 150 academically talented, socioeconomically disadvantaged young men and women to make progress towards gaining leadership and employment skills that will enable them to access economic opportunities and to contribute to positive change in Haiti.
The project has two interconnected objectives:
Internships & Career Services: To plan and implement an internship program enabling HELP students to contribute to capacity building for, and access potential employment opportunities at, local development organizations, including ARC and its international affiliates and partners;
Leadership Program: To build the capacity of HELP’s four-year leadership curriculum providing access to training in leadership, civics, citizenship, and community service to a student body of 150, including the expansion of HELP’s nationwide outreach activities that provide secondary school students across the country with knowledge of educational opportunities available at HELP, with a particular focus on connecting HELP students with ARC-affiliated youth group members in the Carrefour Feuilles neighborhood through community engagement activities.
